nodes.bodyText: If we choose to keep the message sent from osgp-core to domain-core, this logging can be set to debug in my opinion. Or we could remove this message processor altogether, and remove the sending of the message in osgp-core.

In the latter case: how will we handle    this.firmwareManagementService.handleSsldPendingFirmwareUpdate(messageMetadata.getDeviceIdentification());
in CommonConfirmRegisterDeviceRequestMessageProcessor? Where will we handle pending firmware updates?

As discussed earlier, probably the best solution is to not send the message from core to domain if it is not going to be handled in any meaningful way.
Handling pending firmware updates has (presumably after Joost's comment) been added in processMessage of the CommonConfirmRegisterDeviceRequestMessageProcessor (which could probably use a name reflecting its meaning in the platform more than the interaction in the OSLP protocol).
The pending firmware records are checked by the implementation of the other message processor.
These additional steps for handleUpdateFirmwareRequest() are the only real update for the OslpChannelHandler class.  All other changes seem formatting related.

Ha, the answer to something I already noticed. I left some comments in other parts of the code as well.
Since they apparently only concern changes due to reformatting, doing something about them can be considered optional (use your own judgement).
I don't know if this new class is useful. Sending the device type along with some other data doesn't seem to offer any benefit.

What's the reason to make this method static?
It probably works if the tests run fine, but why deviate from the common way step methods are defined?
If there is no reason it looks sloppy just mixing instance and static methods randomly.
I agree, I removed the static keyword.

What's the reason to make this method static?
It probably works if the tests run fine, but why deviate from the common way step methods are defined?
If there is no reason it looks sloppy just mixing instance and static methods randomly.
I agree, I removed the static keyword.

I am having some doubts about the usefulness of adding the requireNonNull here.
My least important objection, but this may be a matter of taste, is that the message from Objects.requireNonNull (which throws a NullPointerException for null) is not significantly more clear than the NullPointerException that would be thrown otherwise by the switch, while it does add some extra code.
The other reason is that the check looks pointless. Given the if condition (receivedConfiguration.getLightType() != null) and the earlier assertion (assertThat(receivedConfiguration.getLightType()).isEqualTo(expectedLightType)) I would say that expectedLightType cannot be null at this point in the code.
The assert function which is executed before the switch will throw an error in case the value is null. Removed the requireNoNull.

Not from this change, but the addition of final makes it even more obvious that meterType won't be reassigned.
It does not look very nice to have the declaration and assignment split in two without need.
Pragmatically speaking, this may best be ignored, since the meter type is being removed as part of FLEX-3787 (assuming the story gets finished as planned).

I made the declaration and assignment 1 statement. Could end up causing a merge conflict for your work as part of 3787, but the formatting and save actions from Eclise prevent me from removing the final keyword (or I would have to do some trickery, like edit the class with vi or something...).
Any reason for the two line gap between the methods?

The most likely reason is the difference between IntelliJ and Eclipse formatting / save actions. Since I made a change to the class and Eclipse performed formatting and save actions, the extra empty lines disappeared.

This is just fine, but may I advocate making use of the assertj assertions for more specialised cases?
Semantically and message-wise you often can get a nicer result when you make use of these less basic options.
If you begin with assertThat(e) you get a ThrowableAssert instead of a StringAssert like with the current code.
This ThrowableAssert has a hasMessage(String) that would do the same check as done here, and offers a whole number of other options as well.
The suggested improvements sound very good. I updated theRegisterDeviceResponseContains() and theConfirmRegisterDeviceResponseContains() accordingly.

I wouldn't have done this myself, and can imagine someone changing it back with other changes.
As we don't have any explicit agreement on how to handle this, this is not a request for change per se, but more taking the opportunity to discuss it a bit.
Language-wise there is nothing wrong with the change and it just works.
Stylisticly I am not to big a fan of static methods, as these can make testing harder in some cases.
A more puristic way of looking may be that this method belongs in an IpAddressConverter or something like that (don't know if it is really pragmatic to go as far and move it, for the nicer design and possible re-use).

I agree with your point of view. In this case, I decided not to remove the static keyword. The method is not acting on or using any instance fields, and testing the test code is not something I think is worth considering.

Maybe this should be renamed. We had a discussion whether the current name is too OSLP-protocol-related, and should rather be more platform oriented.
After the rename, there may still be another issue (depending on the final name) and that can be explained by scrolling down the enums in this MessageType until you see the following comment:
// keep MessageType in alphabetical order.
As far as I can tell this order would be important because of the way we have a number of different enums - DeviceFunction is an example - containing essentially the same list of values (I know, it ain't pretty, but that is for another time).
This could be because we have/had some code in message processors (or elsewhere) that depends on the ordinal of the enums resolved by name.
We may need to look into it better to see if it is still valid and so, if it can be changed so that it no longer applies.
For now my advice would be to keep things in alphabetical order, as the comment says.

If the value 2000 makes sense in all kinds of scenarios it is probably good enough for now.
If we can already foresee that it would come in handy to set this to smaller or larger values for local cucumber tests, general test environment use and something like nightly tests for instance, it may be good to make it configurable, for example through the properties file.
This is an existing delay, not updating or moving it to properties for now.

Similar as with the device registration delay. If we can already imagine a realistic chance that variation across environments of the specific delay will come in handy, it could be better to make it configurable.
If this is deemed OK in different use cases, I think it might be good enough as it is.

Opinions may differ, so I won't go on about this if it is left in, but I am no fan of comments that don't add anything that isn't already obvious from method names or other things in the code.
For me this looks like the category of comments to be avoided like: x = x + 1; // increment x by 1.
I removed the useless comment.

The "likely" here looks a little suspicious. Could it be made somewhat safer if the delay sending the device registration were included as a method parameter of sendDelayedDeviceRegistration just above here?
Further, like before, if the delays are likely suitable for different environments it is OK as it is, but if we already think there is a realistic chance we would like to vary this between different uses, it might be an idea to make them configurable.
